I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s support for strengthening Sri Lanka’s public finances 
began in October 1999 with the approval of the Strengthening Public Expenditure Management 
Systems  technical  assistance  (TA)  project.1 Key  contributions  under  the  TA  included  the 
development of a budget accounting software system still in use today, improved budget and 
planning procedures, and improved investment planning. This was followed in August 2002 with 
the  Public  Sector  Resource  Management  TA  project.2 It  provided  background  studies  and 
recommendations for modernizing the revenue administration. In December 2004 and based on 
the TA findings, the Fiscal Management Reform Program (FMRP)3 was approved. The FMRP, a 
sector development program, principally focused on restructuring and modernizing the revenue 
administration.  
 
2.  The FMRP was closed in June 2008 following the release of the third and final tranche. 
The closing deadline for the accompanying investment and TA loans has been extended to 
continue the support for ongoing procurement and capacity-building initiatives. The FMRP led to 
the successful transformation of the revenue department, improvement of revenue collection, 
and narrowing of the country’s fiscal deficit. The Sri Lanka country operations business plan 
(2007–2008) of October 20064 included a TA project to prepare the second phase of fiscal 
management for 2007. The Sri Lanka country operations business plan (2008) of February 
20085 includes  the  same  TA  for  2008  and  the  Fiscal  Management  and  Service  Delivery 
Program as a firm loan for 2009.  
 
3.  In December 2007, a mission to review the third tranche of the FMRP held a preliminary 
discussion with the Government on a potential follow-up program of the FMRP. Subsequently, 
in May 2008 and at the request of the Ministry of Finance and Planning (MOFP), another review 
mission held follow-up discussions with the Government on the scope of a follow-up second 
phase, i.e., Deepening of Fiscal Management Reform Program and required preparatory work. 
The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) was prepared based on the mission’s 
findings.6 This PPTA is consistent with the Sri Lanka country strategy and program (2004–
2008),7 which focuses on three main areas (i) economic reform, (ii) governance, and (iii) social 
development.8 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Important achievements under the FMRP include the modernization of the revenue 
administration leading to the restructuring of the three revenue departments and adoption of 
human resource management plans to include the introduction of (i) job descriptions for senior 
grade positions, (ii) performance appraisal system, (iii) guidelines for merit-based appointments,

(iv)  guidelines  of  promotion  schemes,  (v)  recruitment  of  staff,  and  (vi)  development  of  an 
extensive training program for cadres. In addition, as part of increasing tax effort, 79,000 new 
tax files have been opened since 2006, including nearly 4,000 for public servants. These are 
expected to increase income tax revenues over the medium term. This follows a situation where 
no civil servant was liable for non-pay-as-you-earn income tax prior to the FMRP. Important tax 
holidays under the Board of Investment Act have been removed in preparation for strengthening 
corporate income tax. These measures have led to an estimated average increase in revenue 
collection of 16.1% of gross domestic product (GDP) during 2005–2007 from 15.3% in 2004. 
Fiscal reporting activities were enhanced significantly, including the issuance of the Fiscal 
Management  Report 9  which  includes  the  Government's  medium-term  fiscal  framework, 
contingent liabilities, variance analysis of revenue collection and expenditures, and underlying 
assumptions supporting the fiscal framework. 
 
5.  Despite the Government's continued efforts and achievements under the FMRP, Sri 
Lanka's fiscal reform program is not complete. The fiscal deficit—while having been reduced 
from 8.2% of GDP in 2004 to 7.7% in 2007—requires further consolidation to restore economic 
fundamentals and thereby enhance macroeconomic stability. From a welfare position, national 
debt remains large, despite having declined from 106% of GDP in 2004 to 86% in 2007. Interest 
payment  on  this  debt  continues  to  absorb  a  large  share  of  current  expenditure—thereby 
diverting it from more productive or welfare-enhancing objectives. 
 
6.  Expenditure containment measures have faced the greatest hurdles. While the FMRP 
was successful in introducing expenditure ceiling frameworks and notions of performance-based 
budgeting, public expenditure as a share of GDP has not stabilized. Reasons behind this reflect 
Government policy priorities, including Government attempts to insulate the population against 
increases in international prices of fuel, food, fertilizer, and other inputs through price subsidies. 
The  impact  of  the  conflict  on  security  spending  has  also  led  to  limited  progress  on  the 
expenditure  front.  Finally,  efforts  under  the  FMRP  to  reduce  expenditure  by  restructuring 
ministries have made little progress. Looking forward, the Government now has a majority in 
Parliament that should increase the likelihood of confronting politically sensitive expenditure 
compression measures. The elimination of fuel subsidies announced in the 2008 budget and 
introduced in late May 2008 may be the first of such measures. The following areas are 
identified for review under the PPTA. 
 
7.  Public Expenditure Reviews. Expenditure rationalization requires an in-depth review of 
trends in spending; analysis of breakdown of spending; and most importantly, effectiveness of 
spending. Three sectors are targeted—agriculture, education, and health. These three sectors 
account  for  the  majority  of  public  spending; and  more  critically,  overlap  between  national, 
subnational, and provincial government spending decisions for education and health could be 
significant. The PPTA will develop background studies that target fiscal consolidation measures 
including preparation of PERs to identify savings from unproductive and even duplication of 
spending  across  selective  central  ministries  and  between  central  and  provincial 
administrations.10 In  addition,  as  part  of  the  PER,  the  PPTA  will  analyze  the  impact  of 
Government subsidies and whether these can be improved through a review and, possibly, 
better targeting.  
 
8.  Service  Delivery  Framework.  Any  implementation  of  additional  fiscal  consolidation 
measures will need to safeguard the quality of service delivery. Accordingly, the PER will have

3 
to be complemented by an assessment of the quality and outreach of existing government 
provision of key goods and services. This will build on previous work undertaken under the 
FMRP to develop results-based budget indicators.11 The PPTA will give careful consideration to 
the sequencing of PERs with the development of a service delivery framework to ensure that 
any  rationalization  effort  will  not  affect  service  delivery  quality.  This  will  be  paramount  for 
reaching  a consensus on  moving  forward  on the  fiscal consolidation  agenda.  The  service 
delivery framework will target the agriculture, education, and health sectors. 
 
9.  Management Audit. A management audit department was recently established as part 
of MOFP restructuring. The department is now seeking advisory support to roll out key functions 
assigned to it, including developing performance-based budget auditing and assessing financial 
management of treasury operations. The PPTA is expected to adopt best international practices 
to  develop  systems  and  procedures  in  these  areas  to  improve  ex-post  monitoring  and 
effectiveness of public spending. 
 
10.  Treasury Fund Transfer System (TFTS). A significant achievement under the FMRP is 
the development of a centrally managed TFTS to strengthen the Treasury Department’s cash 
management system. Direct benefits include increasing the speed of collecting and processing 
receipts, and increasing supervisory capabilities at MOFP, other ministries and departments. 
MOFP  envisages  deepening  reforms  under  the  TFTS  and  comparing  international  best 
practices to include extending work into a treasury single account system as a step to the 
development  of  the  public  accounting  and  financial  management  information  system. 
Accordingly, the combination of background studies on PER, service delivery, management 
audit functions, and TFTS will serve to establish a robust and complete approach to improve 
expenditure management and safeguard the quality of overall spending.   
 
11.  Revenue  Administrations  at  Provincial  Councils.  Fiscal  decentralization  remains 
beset by imbalances between spending powers and limited efforts by provincial administrations 
to  develop  their  own  revenue.  Recommendations  under  the  FMRP  are  gradually  being 
implemented. While provincial administrations have made recent improvements to increasing 
their own revenue, selective provincial councils will need to identify new policy and institutional 
measures  to  reduce  dependency  on  central  transfers  and  expand  financing  of  public 
infrastructure.   
 
12.  Capacity Development. Institutionalizing capacity development is another key area that 
the Government has requested continued support from ADB. The FMRP gave an impetus to 
this area that was neglected for a considerable period of time. A cross-section of officers 
working on fiscal management at MOFP and revenue departments in all grades got intensive 
training under the FMRP, in Sri Lanka as well as abroad. While foreign training is the most 
effective option for certain subjects, there is also a need to setup a dedicated training institution 
in Sri Lanka. This institution is expected to facilitate training and knowledge enhancement in the 
area of public fiscal management on a sustainable basis in order to improve the overall quality 
of the services provided by them.  
 
 
 
                                                 
11 It will also provide continuity to work supported by the World Bank to improve primary education.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The PPTA will support the preparation and design of the proposed program which is 
envisaged to deepen and enlarge reforms under the FMRP and ensure that the Government 
has  relevant  analysis  and  information  for  effective  decision-making  in  support  of  fiscal 
consolidation and, in particular, contribute to achieving the Government's revised target of a 
fiscal deficit of 5% of GDP and a national debt of 82% of GDP by 2010.12   
 
14.  The PPTA will develop background studies to provide inputs for the design of a policy 
framework to support (i) continuity of reforms initiated under the FMRP (i.e., strengthening 
revenue-generating efforts at selected provincial councils); (ii) deepening of reforms following 
the FMRP (i.e., application of PERs, extension of the TFTS, and establishment of a training 
institution for public fiscal management); and (iii) complementary reforms following the FMRP 
(i.e.,  developing  capacity  for  management  audit  functions  of  MOFP  and  developing  the 
foundations for a service delivery framework).  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The  PPTA  will  assist  in  identifying  core  expenditure  containment  measures, 
complemented  by  medium-term  revenue  measures,  to  support  the  Government's  fiscal 
consolidation program. On the expenditure side, expected outputs include developing (i) a 
comprehensive  review  of  public  expenditures  in  three  sectors—agriculture,  education,  and 
health with the objective of identifying expenditure containment measures in the sectors; and (ii) 
a proposal for developing management audit functions at MOFP to develop improved systems 
and methods to increase effectiveness of spending and enhance reporting on public spending. 
On the revenue side, the PPTA will prepare an assessment and a blueprint for moving to a 
modernized and streamlined revenue administration in two provincial councils. These fiscal 
support measures will be complemented by developing (i) a concept paper to assess the state 
of service delivery in the three sectors, and a service delivery framework to ensure improved 
effectiveness and quality of service delivery over the medium term; (ii) a proposal for deepening 
TFTS reforms with the view to adopting best practices on extending the existing systems to a 
treasury single account system, and building structure for development of a public accounting 
and financial management information system; and (iii) a proposal for the establishment of a 
training institution for sustainable capacity development in the area of public fiscal management. 
 
16.  The PPTA will have two parts. Part 1 will conduct a detailed needs assessment of the 
various components—and in particular the deficiencies in the system—by working closely with 
stakeholders and building on work undertaken by the Government and other development 
partners. Part 2 will design a sequenced policy and institutional development framework with 
specific recommendations to address deficiencies identified by the needs assessment. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $360,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will 
provide the equivalent of $60,000 to finance part of the local currency costs for counterpart staff,

informed that the approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing program. 
The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The MOFP will serve as the Executing Agency for the PPTA and be responsible for 
PPTA implementation. A senior MOFP official, preferably from the Fiscal Policy Department or 
National Budget Department, will be designated as the project director. A steering committee, to 
be chaired by the secretary to the Treasury will be established and have representatives from 
the  Fiscal Policy  Department,  National  Budget  Department,  National  Planning  Department, 
Treasury  Operations  Department,  and  Management  Audit  Department;  and  three  sector 
directors of the ministries of agriculture, education, and health. Revenue department heads of 
the two provincial councils will be asked to attend meetings for relevant discussions. The 
steering committee may invite other parties to attend its meetings, if necessary to achieve 
specific PPTA objectives. The committee, which will meet at least once every quarter, will be 
mandated to (i) monitor and guide PPTA implementation, (ii) resolve issues that might arise in 
its execution and implementation, and (iii) review PPTA consultants’ reports. Whenever possible, 
ADB staff will attend the steering committee meetings as observers. 
 
19.  Consulting  services  required  for  the  PPTA  include  3  international  consultants  for  5 
person-months of international consulting and 10 national consultants for 20 person-months of 
national consulting. The international and national consultants will be mobilized intermittently 
over 6 months. A consulting firm will be selected using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method with the simplified technical proposals. Three national consultants, namely one public 
expenditure expert, one training expert, and one management audit expert, will be recruited 
individually by ADB using the single-source selection method. The recruitment of the firm and 
the individual national consultants will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
20.  The  MOFP  will  provide  office  space,  furniture,  and  logistical  and  all  administrative 
support necessary to implement the PPTA. Office equipment and software to be financed by the 
PPTA will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended 
from time to time). Equipment procured under the PPTA will be transferred to the Government 
upon  PPTA  completion.  The  PPTA  is  expected  to  be  implemented  over  6  months,  from 
November 2008 to May 2009. The PPTA findings will be presented in a workshop at the end of 
the PPTA.  
 
21.  The World Bank is currently processing a public sector capacity-building project, which is 
scheduled for approval in June 2008. While the proposed ensuing ADB program and the World 
Bank project will both assist in strengthening public financial management capacity in a broad 
sense, subsector demarcation between the two projects is clear as the proposed World Bank 
project comprises components that do not overlap with the ADB program (i) upgrading statistical 
capacity at the Department of Census and Statistics, and (ii) improving audit standards at the 
Auditor General’s Department.  
 
22.  The PPTA is classified as a general poverty intervention. The initial poverty and social 
analysis is in Appendix 4.

6 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Sri Lanka for preparing the Deepening of Fiscal Management Reforms, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Management Audit Expert and Team Leader (international, 3 person-months)  
1.  The expert will have proven experience in financial management of large public entities 
and  have  worked  in  a  public  sector  internal  and/or  performance  audit  environment  for  a 
minimum of 5 years, including significant exposure to performance audit. Preferably he/she will 
be an accountant and possess a professional qualification in internal auditing and/or have 
managed a national internal/performance audit unit. Major responsibilities include the following.  
 
(i)  Review job description and competences of newly developed management audit 
department at the Ministry of Finance and Planning (MOFP).  
(ii)  Review organization structure and internal audit arrangements and functions at 
MOFP, including in the revenue departments. 
(iii)  Review operating practices for financial management and flow of funds, focusing 
on areas of improvement. 
(iv)  Contrast operating procedures and other management audit functions with best 
international practices. 
(v)  Assist with establishing the organization structure, institutional framework, and 
operations of the management audit department.  
(vi)  Prepare human resource policies, training programs, and other critical inputs to 
develop and strengthen management audit activities. 
(vii)  Identify  areas  for  piloting  cross-sectional  management  audit  task  force  and 
assess human resource requirements to carry out the expected tasks. 
(viii)  Develop  a  brief  action  plan  for  performance-based  budget  auditing  and 
assessment of financial management of treasury operations. 
(ix)  Develop  a  comprehensive  management  audit  manual  based  on  risk-based 
auditing and performance-based budget auditing methodology by updating the 
existing internal audit manual.   
(x)  Prepare a final report, in coordination with the national management audit expert, 
on strengthening MOFP’s management audit department, addressing items (i)–
(ix).  
(xi)  Present findings at the final workshop in association with the national training 
expert. 
(xii)  Advise the national training expert in institutionalizing capacity development in 
the  area  of  public  fiscal  management  from  the  international  best  practice 
viewpoint. 
(xiii)  Manage and supervise the activities of national consultants in each sector and 
closely coordinate with other international experts.  
 
B.  Treasury Management Expert (international, 1 person-month) 
2.  The expert will have proven experience in national/subnational treasury management 
and an educational background in economics/public finance. Preferably he/she will have a 
significant information technology background, including automation of treasury management 
systems. Major responsibilities include the following. 
 
(i)  Review the treasury fund transfer system (TFTS) at MOFP, including the layers 
of bank accounts and the latest cash management practices. 
(ii)  Compare existing TFTS and operating practices with international best practices. 
(iii)  Identify areas for reform and extension, and estimate required time and costs.

Appendix 3  13 
(iv)  Assess potential fiscal savings from adopting a treasury single account system. 
(v)  Identify potential issues to be encountered and actions needed to extend the 
TFTS into a treasury single account system, and then to a public accounting and 
financial management information system.  
(vi)  Prepare a final report including a time-bound action plan with recommendations 
to  develop  and  roll  out  a  treasury  single  account  with  milestones  and 
procurement plans addressing items (i)–(v).  
(vii)  In coordination with the national training expert, disseminate the findings through 
workshops and/or training programs.  
 
C.  Revenue Management Expert (international, 1 person-month) 
3.  The  expert  will  have  proven  experience  in  fiscal  management  reforms  and  an 
educational background in economics/public finance. Preferably he/she will have experience in 
fiscal decentralization. Major responsibilities include the following. 
 
(i)  Review  revenue  administration  systems  and  procedures  at  the  two  selected 
provincial councils. 
(ii)  Compare existing systems and procedures at provincial councils with those of 
the central Government and with international best practices. 
(iii)  Identify areas where provincial councils can pursue further fiscal independence. 
Especially,  identify  potential  tax  and  other  revenue  sources  whose  revenue 
authority can be transferred from the central Government to provincial councils.  
(iv)  Assess physical, institutional, and capacity bottlenecks to enhance provincial 
councils’ fiscal independence and to improve revenue administration in general. 
(v)  Identify a process of re-engineering possibilities in administering turnover taxes 
and stamp duties.  
(vi)  Prepare,  in  coordination  with  the  national  revenue  expert,  a  final  report 
comprising an action plan for developing a modernized and streamlined revenue 
administration addressing items (i)–(v), with milestones and procurement plans. 
(vii)  Present findings at the final workshop in association with the national training and 
revenue experts. 
(viii)  Manage and supervise the activities of the national revenue experts. 
 
D.  Public  Expenditure  Experts  (3 national experts, out of which one to be recruited 
individually, 6 person-months in total)  
4.  The  experts  will  comprise  3  consultants  each  to  be  responsible  for  a  sector  on 
agriculture,  education,  and  health  (2  person-months  each).  The  experts  will  have  proven 
experience in the area of budget and expenditure management of the respective sector and 
have strong analytical skills. The experts will have at least 5 years of exposure to public 
expenditure reviews and relevant educational background in economics and/or finance. Major 
responsibilities include the following. 
 
(i)  In coordination with the national service delivery experts, review recent policies, 
priorities, and track record on public expenditures in the respective sectors. 
(ii)  Undertake interviews with key public officials to assess their understanding of 
public expenditure policies and practices.    
(iii)  Assess the performance of budget programming from a sector perspective and 
identify weaknesses and inadequacies.

14  Appendix 3 
(iv)  Prepare recommendations on how to strengthen expenditure controls, building 
on the expenditure ceilings framework. 
(v)  Assess compliance with top–down (or intersector) versus bottom–up (intrasector) 
approach to budgeting.    
(vi)  Assess effective adoption of strategic approach to budgeting. 
(vii)  Prepare project appraisal guidelines to support identification and selection of 
investment projects in three sectors. 
(viii)  Prepare  evaluation  methodology  of  completed  investment  projects  to  assess 
effectiveness of spending. 
(ix)  Assess  effectiveness  of  public  spending  across  the  three  sectors  and 
recommend measures to increase effectiveness of spending. 
(x)  Assess the government subsidy programs allocated from the budget in the sector 
and recommend measures to improve effectiveness of subsidies, through such 
measures as subsidy reduction and better targeting. 
(xi)  Identify possible sources of budget savings across the line ministries for more 
effective use of spending. 
(xii)  Prepare a final report on the review of public expenditures in the three respective 
sectors addressing items (i)–(xi) and present findings at the final workshop in 
association with the national training expert. 
 
E.  Service Delivery Experts (3 national experts, 6 person-months in total) 
5.  The  experts  will  comprise  3  consultants;  each  will  be  responsible  for  a  sector  on 
agriculture,  education,  and  health  (2  person-months  each).  The  experts  will  have  proven 
experience  in  the  area  of  public  service  delivery  and  evaluation  of  public  administration. 
Preferably, he/she will have significant experience in public administration reforms in developing 
countries. Major responsibilities include the following. 
 
(i)  In coordination with the public expenditure experts, undertake a comprehensive 
review of the service delivery capacity and status in the three key sectors. 
(ii)  Assess effectiveness of service delivery against commitments under the national 
development plan, Millennium Development Goals, and other national or sector 
objectives. 
(iii)  Assess various initiatives supported by development partners in the areas of 
service delivery reforms with particular focus on previous World Bank support. 
(iv)  Assess weaknesses and inadequacies of service delivery by meeting service 
delivery recipients of the key sectors. 
(v)  Assess outsourcing of service delivery in the three sectors and how it compares 
with central and provincial government direct providers.  
(vi)  Review  results-based  indicators  in  four  pilot  ministries  introduced  under  the 
Fiscal Management Reform Program and scope for integration of existing work 
under the proposed service delivery framework. 
(vii)  Assess human resource needs and create a human resource development plan 
building across national Government (line ministries) and provincial councils. 
(viii)  Identify skill requirements for staff and develop a training plan.  
(ix)  Develop a service delivery framework to improve effectiveness and quality of 
service  delivery  that  comprises  a  plan  for  (a)  analyzing  public  expenditure 
incidence,  (b)  reforming  institutions  and  management,  (c)  strengthening  the 
relationship of accountability among various groups, and (d) identifying critical 
incentives in ensuring quality service delivery.

Appendix 3  15 
(x)  Prepare a final report on strengthening service delivery in Sri Lanka across three 
sectors addressing items (i)–(ix) and present findings at the final workshop in 
association with the national training expert. 
 
F.  Training Expert (national, to be recruited individually, 3 person-months) 
6.  The expert will have proven experience in the area of training in revenue, fiscal and 
financial  management,  and  possess  a  degree  or  a  post  graduate  qualification.  Preferably, 
he/she will have worked in training and/or workshops at the MOFP or with the Government. 
Major responsibilities include the following. 
 
(i)  In  coordination  with  other  experts,  undertake  comprehensive  training  needs 
assessments in each respective reform area to support institutional strengthening 
across activities covered under the technical assistance.  
(ii)  Review  existing  training  programs  at  treasury  departments  and  at  provincial 
councils. 
(iii)  In coordination with other experts and based on the needs assessments and the 
review of existing programs, identify areas where new training programs and 
workshops  are  necessary  to  ensure  sustainability  of  reforms  in  public  fiscal 
management.  
(iv)  Prepare recommendations on how to institutionalize the process in (i)–(iii) to 
ensure that the training needs assessments will be conducted and the necessary 
training programs and workshops will be introduced accordingly on a sustainable 
basis to support implementation of these reforms under the proposed Deepening 
of Fiscal Management Reform Program. 
(v)  Prepare an action plan for the establishment of a dedicated training institution to 
facilitate  training  and  knowledge  enhancement  in  the  area  of  public  fiscal 
management on a sustainable basis.  
(vi)  Identify and recommend external institutions and programs that offer appropriate 
training courses for concerned staff. 
(vii)  Prepare a final report on the review of training needs and outlook addressing 
items (i)–(vi). 
(viii)  Conduct workshops and assist other experts in disseminating their findings. 
 
G.  Management Audit Expert (national, to be recruited individually, 3 person months)  
7.  The expert will have proven experience in financial management of large public entities 
and have worked in a public sector internal and/or performance audit, including significant 
exposure  to  performance  audits.  Preferably,  he/she  will  be  an  accountant  and  possess 
professional qualification in internal auditing and/or have managed a performance audit unit of 
large public entities. Major responsibilities include the following. 
 
(i)  In  coordination  with  the  international  management  audit  expert,  review  the 
organization structure and operating practices of the newly developed MOFP 
management  audit  department,  as  well  as  other  internal  audit  units  in  the 
revenue departments. 
(ii)  Undertake  interviews  with  key  public  officials and  help  with  the  international 
management audit expert’s activities to strengthen management audit activities 
and pilot cross-sectional task forces.

16  Appendix 3 
(iii)  Assist the international management audit expert in developing a comprehensive 
management audit manual, focusing on performance audit, organizational audit, 
and systemic and procedural analyses. 
(iv)  Present findings at the final workshop in association with the national training and 
international management audit experts. 
 
H.  Revenue Experts (2 national experts, 2 person-months in total) 
8.  The experts will comprise 2 consultants; each will be responsible for one of the two 
selected provincial councils (one person-month each). The experts will have proven experience 
in fiscal management reforms and an educational background in economics/public finance. 
Preferably, he/she will have experience in subnational tax reforms. Major responsibilities include 
the following. 
 
(i)  In  coordination  with  the  international  revenue  management  expert,  review 
revenue administration systems and procedures at the selected provincial council. 
(ii)  Undertake interviews with key public officials at the provincial council and with 
other potential stakeholders. 
(iii)  Assist  the  international  revenue  management  expert  in  identifying  and 
addressing bottlenecks in order to strengthen revenue efforts with a focus on tax 
administration, including systems and procedures, tax rates, and provincial tax 
base. 
(iv)  Assist the international revenue management expert in recommending measures 
to  strengthen  tax  and  nontax  revenue  collection  at  the  selected  provincial 
councils for the short and medium term. 
(v)  In coordination with the international revenue management expert assist in the 
preparing a final report addressing (i)–(iv) and comprising an action plan for 
developing a modernized and streamlined revenue administration. 
(vi)  Present findings at the final workshop in association with the national training and 
international revenue management experts.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy, and the sector analysis describe how the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy of the 
partner country. 
 
Mahinda Chintana, the Government of Sri Lanka's comprehensive strategic development plan, 2006–2016, sets out a vision to 
ensure Sri Lanka's long-term economic development and poverty reduction objectives. Infrastructure development, combined 
with development of a knowledge economy, is at the core of the strategy. Medium-term financial stability with the gradual 
reduction of the long-standing budget deficit and national debt provides the macroeconomic foundations to support the strategy. 
The Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act of 2003 underpins the Government's statutory commitment to fiscal stability and 
associated reporting requirements. 
 
The Fiscal Management Reform Program (FMRP), approved in December 2004, was designed to support the strengthening of 
public finances by improving public resource and expenditure management systems, promoting fiscal discipline, and supporting 
fiscal decentralization. The FMRP has made important progress in such areas as increased revenue collection, reflecting the 
modernization of the revenue administration, resulting in improved fiscal performance. The FMRP was closed in June 2008 
following the release of the third and final tranche. The Government has expressed interest in pursuing a follow-up program.  
 
In view of the rapidly changing and uncertain security situation during 2007 and more recently the Government's formal 
termination of the cease-fire agreement in early January 2008, the completion of the country partnership strategy has been 
delayed and is currently expected to be submitted for consideration by the Asian Development Bank‘s Board of Directors in 
August 2008. The latest country strategy and program update was issued in August 2005 prior to Mahinda Chintana and the 
formation of the current Government. The country strategy and program focuses on three areas (i) economic reform, (ii) 
governance, and (iii) social development. The Sri Lanka country operations business plan 2008 of February 2008a includes the 
project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) for the follow-up project: Preparing the Deepening of Fiscal Management 
Reforms as a standby project for 2008. 
 
The PPTA envisages contributing indirectly to poverty reduction through sustainable fiscal management and good governance. 
Strengthening fiscal management ultimately supports the development of a sustainable public service delivery mechanism that 
contributes to improved social welfare and that, in turn, helps the poor. Furthermore, macroeconomic stability in general will 
contribute to pro-poor economic growth, as opposed to macroeconomic turmoil, which often adversely affects the poor. The 
PPTA may also contribute to enhancing good governance and more effective use of targeting that can also serve to reduce the 
plight of the poor.  
 
B.  Targeting Classification 
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H)   Geographic (TI-G)   Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
 
2.  Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
The ensuing program will comprise a policy (program) component with a limited set of policy actions and a procurement 
component, which does not have any targeted intervention. It may also include a capacity-building component.  
 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
 
The following will be conducted (i) the Government’s poverty reduction strategy will be reviewed and its consistency with the 
ensuing program checked; (ii) analysis and assessment will be conducted with regard to the channels through which the 
program contributes to poverty reduction; (iii) analysis will be made if any of the program components can potentially affect the 
poor adversely, and measures will be developed if any.

18  Appendix 4 
 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? 
 
National consultants will be advised to assess the impact channels for poverty reduction in each subsector/component and to 
assess any unforeseen adverse effect on the poor.  
 
3.  If  GI,  is  there  any  opportunity  for  pro-poor  design  (e.g.,  social  inclusion  subcomponents,  cross  subsidy,  pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
 
No specific design is planned at this stage since the PPTA focuses on upstream policy reforms such as reviewing expenditure 
management at line ministries. Better targeting of subsidies will be reviewed in order to improve effectiveness as this may 
include an impact on the poor.  
 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from the 
project? 
 
Recipients of public services in general will be the potential beneficiaries. Benefits from macroeconomic stability and enhanced 
service delivery will not discriminate against the poor and the socially excluded. 
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
Assurances that public services do not deteriorate as a result of the public expenditure review.  
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project address them? 
 
Fiscal consolidation is politically sensitive and needs to be implemented judiciously. The PPTA will provide the background 
work and detailed analysis to support informed decision-making and thereby facilitate implementation of measures to address 
fiscal shortcomings while improving the effectiveness of public spending and overall quality and outreach of service delivery.   
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Indicate the potential initial stakeholders.  
 
Ministry of Finance and Planning, key line ministries, provincial councils, and taxpayers. 
 
2.  What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., workshops, 
community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations, etc.)? 
 
With regards to public expenditure review, stakeholders of respective sectors such as provincial councils and service recipients 
will be consulted. Service delivery beneficiaries and providers will also be consulted. Workshops will be planned to disseminate 
the outputs.  
 
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
     Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
 
4.  Will a C&P plan be prepared?    Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
Not required at this stage and based on recommendations may be included under the subsequent capacity building component 
of the loan. 
 
 
C.  Gender and Development 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
 
No specific issue is envisaged at this stage. 
 
2.  Does the proposed project/program have the potential to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment by 
improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and participation in decision making?
